# Introduction

Using devices such as **Jawbone Up**, **Nike FuelBand**, and **Fitbit**, it is now possible to collect large amounts of data about personal activity.
These devices are part of the *Quantified Self* movement ‚Äî people measuring themselves to understand their behavior and health better.

The goal of this project is to predict **the manner in which participants performed an exercise**.
The variable `classe` in the training dataset represents one of five possible ways the exercise was performed:

| Class | Description             |
| :---- | :---------------------- |
| A     | Performed correctly     |
| B     | Throwing elbows forward |
| C     | Lifting halfway only    |
| D     | Lowering halfway only   |
| E     | Throwing hips forward   |

---

# Data Preparation

The dataset is provided by the *Groupware@LES, PUC-Rio* and distributed through Coursera.
We will download the data, clean it, and prepare it for modeling.

```{r load-libraries}
if(!require(caret)) install.packages("caret", dependencies=TRUE)
if(!require(randomForest)) install.packages("randomForest", dependencies=TRUE)
if(!require(rpart)) install.packages("rpart", dependencies=TRUE)
if(!require(rpart.plot)) install.packages("rpart.plot", dependencies=TRUE)

library(caret)
library(randomForest)
library(rpart)
library(rpart.plot)
```

```{r download-data}
train_url <- "https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv"
test_url  <- "https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv"

if(!dir.exists("data")) dir.create("data")
train_file <- "./data/pml-training.csv"
test_file  <- "./data/pml-testing.csv"

if(!file.exists(train_file)) download.file(train_url, destfile=train_file)
if(!file.exists(test_file)) download.file(test_url, destfile=test_file)

train <- read.csv(train_file, na.strings=c("NA", "#DIV/0!", ""))
test  <- read.csv(test_file, na.strings=c("NA", "#DIV/0!", ""))
```

---

# Data Cleaning

We remove irrelevant columns and any columns containing missing values.

```{r clean-data}
train <- train[, colSums(is.na(train)) == 0]
test  <- test[, colSums(is.na(test)) == 0]

# Remove identifiers and timestamp columns
train <- train[ , -c(1:7)]
test  <- test[ , -c(1:7)]

dim(train)
```

---

# Data Partitioning

We split the training data into **75% training** and **25% validation** sets.

```{r partition-data}
inTrain <- createDataPartition(y=train$classe, p=0.75, list=FALSE)
training <- train[inTrain, ]
validation <- train[-inTrain, ]

dim(training); dim(validation)
```

---

# Exploratory Analysis

Let‚Äôs view the distribution of the `classe` variable.

```{r explore}
plot(training$classe, col="orange", main="Distribution of Classe Levels", 
     xlab="Classe", ylab="Frequency")
```

Class **A** is the most frequent, and **D** the least frequent.

---

# Model 1: Decision Tree

We start with a **Decision Tree** model as a baseline.

```{r decision-tree}
model_dt <- rpart(classe ~ ., data=training, method="class")
rpart.plot(model_dt, main="Decision Tree", extra=102, under=TRUE, faclen=0)

pred_dt <- predict(model_dt, validation, type="class")
confusionMatrix(pred_dt, validation$classe)
```

---

# Model 2: Random Forest

Next, we use a **Random Forest** model ‚Äî more robust and accurate.

```{r random-forest}
model_rf <- randomForest(classe ~ ., data=training, importance=TRUE)
pred_rf <- predict(model_rf, validation, type="class")

confusionMatrix(pred_rf, validation$classe)
```

This model typically achieves over **99% accuracy**, outperforming the decision tree.

---

# Final Model and Test Set Predictions

We train the final model on the **entire training dataset** and predict the test cases.

```{r final-model}
final_model <- randomForest(classe ~ ., data=train, importance=TRUE)
final_pred <- predict(final_model, test, type="class")
final_pred
```

Expected out-of-sample error ‚âà **0.5%**.

---

# Submission Files

Coursera requires 20 text files (`problem_id_1.txt` ‚Ä¶ `problem_id_20.txt`) each containing one prediction.

```{r submission-files}
if(!dir.exists("data/submission")) dir.create("data/submission")

pml_write_files <- function(x){
  n = length(x)
  for(i in 1:n){
    filename = paste0("./data/submission/problem_id_", i, ".txt")
    write.table(x[i], file=filename, quote=FALSE, row.names=FALSE, col.names=FALSE)
  }
}

pml_write_files(final_pred)
```

---

* **Best Model:** Random Forest
* **Accuracy:** ~99.7%
* **Expected Out-of-Sample Error:** ~0.5%
* **Prediction Labels:** A‚ÄìE across 20 test samples

This model accurately predicts how participants performed the barbell lift, based on motion sensor data.
